key_points: The Colonial Pipeline resumed operations on Wednesday evening after a cyberattack caused it to shut down, leading to fuel shortages.
The process of returning the pipeline to normal operations is expected to take several days.
The cyberattack sparked debates in Congress over cybersecurity and federal responsibility for public works projects.
President Joe Biden issued an executive order to update the federal government's approach to cybersecurity.
Energy Secretary Jennifer Granholm emphasized the need to strengthen infrastructure against cyber threats.
The hack was reported to the FBI, which then notified the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA).
The FBI identified the criminal organization DarkSide as responsible for the attack.
Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg discussed the need for investment in resilient infrastructure as a national security issue.
The Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration and other agencies are taking measures to mitigate the fuel supply crisis.
Buttigieg views the pipeline incident as a demonstration of the importance of the Biden administration's infrastructure proposal.
spokespersons: Joe Biden (President of the United States)
Frank Pallone Jr. (D-N.J., Chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee)
Cathy McMorris Rodgers (R-Wash., Ranking Member of the Energy and Commerce Committee)
